comments.author: Drew Baker (RoxRock)

comments.text:
First  off, if you just called the crusades a massacre, I agree. Second, I 
never said Great Britain had any mistakes. If they had no mistakes America 
wouldn't be "the best country on earth to me." America most certainly is 
not weak. But England was coming off the "most powerful country in the 
world" title at that time, and choosing to fight rather than negotiate 
wasn't what I would call a good move. Our navy may be mighty now but that 
was started in 1812 when we started to take interest in naval combat. I 
also would like to point out that Napoleon was beaten by a huge coalition, 
notably England. I was simply trying to get rid of people thinking that 
England declared war in 1812, when they were simply trying to pick on what 
they still considered a weaker country for more naval troops. Originally it 
was just supposed to be Englishmen who moved to America (who were still 
citizens), but they didn't care when those born American were abducted. I 
can also say that many of the "war hawks" of the war of 1812 probably just 
wanted a war. I agree, America fought extremely well in that war, but it 
wasn't the smartest decision. It worked out, though, to some extent like 
the declaration of independence. It was idiocy, but we managed to pull 
through, and Americans managed to found the country that will stand in 
history as the land of the free and the home of the brave (a line that 
proves the war of 1812 wasn't entirely useless... Just mostly).
comments.author: Owlblocks David

comments.text:
+Owlblocks David And now we have a Navy that is in a whole league of it's 
own, we beat the troops that beat Napoleon, one of the most credited 
generals on earth, and even though we were out gunned, out manned, we still 
beat them.  Now tell me we're pathetic.  Not to mention they than came to 
us in WWII, though I will give credit for holding out so well during that 
time (Praise to Churchill).  We've made mistakes, but so has Britain and 
every other country *cough* the crusade *cough*.
comments.author: DJ7223

comments.text:
I agree, let's war with every country we have a disagreement with. We can 
treat with them outside their capital :D yeah, they were annoying, but 
there were better solutions. First off, because war should be a last-chance 
option, and second, because it was idiotic. We had somewhere between 16 and 
18 ships to England's hundreds, and while they were fighting Napoleon at 
that time, once they finished they took Washington D.C... Pretty quickly, 
actually. They might have been able to fully conquer America, if they 
weren't tired of war, and not wanted to fight and risk more lives. I don't 
know. New Orleans was a miracle, as was Fort McHenry. I'm not sure our luck 
would have lasted. Of course, New Orleans hadn't happened when the treaty 
was signed. And yes. It has SO many problems. But it's the best country on 
earth to me.
comments.author: Owlblocks David

comments.text: I personally believe it is the best country on Earth.

Since when is Socialism a bad thing? There's a difference between Communism 
and socialism, and a difference between different forms of Communism 
(Marx/Lenin, for example). I don't see anything wrong with socialism (With 
Communism, however...), because both capitalism and socialism have flaws. I 
wouldn't call socialism evil. Both parties have flaws (I don't see why 
there's so much hate over gun control. Just debate it out, see wins, and 
accept it. I personally don't see anything particularly bad with either 
side, because they both have ups and downs. Both sides are attempting to 
make America safer, if through different methods.). I just wouldn't say 
choose "the lesser of two evils". Just don't choose either.

top_comment.text:
You folks amaze me. You make funny satirical sketches about serious 
issues...and somehow you do it without deeply offending anybody. How is 
that possible? And how do we elect you all to positions of higher office?!?﻿
top_comment.author: Adam Thornton

comments.text: Agreed!
comments.author: Penny Ann

comments.text:
Great summary, +ae3qe27u3! It's got a cute and silly "common enemy" who 
speaks to patriotism without anybody REALLY caring, and they fight about 
their caricatured disagreements in a cartoon-style way that nobody can take 
too seriously.

Having seen so much political bile, hate, and violence during the past 14 
years or so, this is really refreshing. It doesn't even begin to tackle the 
actual issues...but maybe more of these gentle parodies are exactly what 
people need to help us out of our ruts.

Personally, I've found it easy to get cynical with age (even here in Canada 
where the fights aren't nearly as vicious). Things like this make me think 
that, eventually, some generation might figure it all out.
comments.author: Adam Thornton

comments.text:
I think a large part of it is that, at the very end, not only is the 
conflict pointed at Britain, thereby drawing hostile attention away from 
intranational politics to a UK with bad teeth, but they also do also fairly 
accurate portrayal of both sides without actually insulting them as a 
whole. In short, the two parties act a lot like you would expect a divorced 
couple to do - arguing, bickering, and picking fault at the other. However, 
because they are in the presence of their "daughter" and the family 
therapist (which indicates that they want want to make a trend effort for 
their daughter), I think it understandable that the "divorced couple" would 
turn indicated down at least a little bit.
comments.author: ae3qe27u3
